\hypertarget{classsockpp_1_1can__socket}{}\label{classsockpp_1_1can__socket}\index{sockpp::can\_socket@{sockpp::can\_socket}}

\doxysubsection{Detailed Description}
Raw Linux CANbus (Socket\+CAN) sockets. 

Raw CAN sockets are comparable to using the old character drivers to send and receive individual CAN frames to one or more interfaces.

According to the Socket\+CAN notes\+: defaults are set at RAW socket binding time\+: \begin{DoxyItemize}
\item The filters are set to exactly one filter receiving everything \item The socket only receives valid data frames (=\texorpdfstring{$>$}{>} no error message frames) \item The loopback of sent CAN frames is enabled (see Local Loopback of Sent Frames) \item The socket does not receive its own sent frames (in loopback mode)\end{DoxyItemize}
These can all be changed by setting options on the socket.

{\footnotesize\ttfamily \label{classsockpp_1_1can__socket_a63f921d7269c2718e5ef313adf851a58}

Sets the filters for receiving CAN frames on this socket. 

A filter matches when\+: \begin{DoxyVerb}* <received_can_id> & mask == can_id & mask
* \end{DoxyVerb}

\hline
{\em n} & The number of CAN filters. \\
\hline
\end{DoxyParams}

{\itshape true} if the filters were set, {\itshape false} otherwise. 
\end{DoxyReturn}

\mbox{\hyperlink{classsockpp_1_1result}{result}} sockpp\+::can\+\_\+socket\+::set\+\_\+filters (\begin{DoxyParamCaption}\item[{const std\+::vector$<$ can\+\_\+filter $>$ \&}]{filters}{}\end{DoxyParamCaption})\hspace{0.3cm}{\ttfamily [inline]}}



Sets the filters for receiving CAN frames on this socket. 

A filter matches when\+: \begin{DoxyVerb}* <received_can_id> & mask == can_id & mask
* \end{DoxyVerb}



\begin{DoxyParams}{Parameters}
{\em filters} & The CAN filters \\
\hline
\end{DoxyParams}
\begin{DoxyReturn}{Returns}
{\itshape true} if the filters were set, {\itshape false} otherwise. 
\end{DoxyReturn}

const int sockpp\+::can\+\_\+socket\+::\+PROTOCOL\+\_\+\+FAMILY = AF\+\_\+\+CAN\hspace{0.3cm}{\ttfamily [static]}}



The Socket\+CAN protocol family. 

Note that AF\+\_\+\+CAN == PF\+\_\+\+CAN, which is used in many of the CAN examples.
